ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot of the intuitive notion of computability, and how that connects to recursive functions, turing machines, and abacus machines through Church's Thesis. We covered the undecidability of First Order Logic, and eventually both of Godel'sm incompleteness theorems.
Understanding first order logic, turing machines, recursive functions, etc.

Insights and intuition required for the understanding of Godel's First and Second Incompleteness Theorems. The importance of the Incompleteness Theorems in the context of mathematics. The underlying logic behind what computability means and what can be computed.
Understanding of Turing machines, Church's theorem, and Godel's incompleteness theorems.
Understanding of godel's theorems and computation theory.
This course taught me to think in a completely new way! I learned a lot about representation and several important results in computability.
Proofs, learn about computability, decidability
Godels Incompleteness Thm.
Thorough understanding of Godel's incompleteness theorems and their implications.
Taking this class taught me advanced meta-mathematics at the level of Gdel's theorems.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The material is very clear and the structure of the course, especially the development of topics, is well made to facilitate learning. However, I didn't particularly enjoy the student presentations (nor did I think they were very helpful in explaining the topics), and I would review all the material again after the presentations. It just comes to show how amazing of an instructor Sun-Joo is, and I'd rather her be the one to explain all the topics than my peers.

The course is well designed for students to understand the material. The materials are organized in a way that is logical and interesting. The material is really interesting and lectures are engaging. Some of the classes are taught through student presentation, the quality of these can vary depending on the group, however, there is enough material handed out to help with the understanding of these contents.
Course was well structured and Prof. Shin was very helpful.
Amazing course. I love Prof Shin.

Strengths: Sunjoo is a wonderful professor and is extraordinarily kind and friendly. She's also incredibly organized and does not hesitate to help you learn the material. 
Weaknesses: There weren't many, but perhaps the presentation expectations could have been a little more clear.
I really enjoyed the conceptual methods of teaching.  Problem sets were quite reasonable.
Lecture can be long and get hard to focus towards end (kind of dry)
Sun-Joo is a wonderful professor! Always take the chance to have a class with her :)
This course well-prepared its students for success as the lectures closely followed a well-written text on the subject.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! One of the most interesting courses I have ever taken conceptually. The entire course builds to Godel's incompleteness theorems and, although we do not spend a lot of time on it, they are fascinating and critical results in math. The professor is super wonderful and you will love her.

Yes, Yes, Yes! Sun-joo is a great instructor, and you'll learn about the "flaws" when you create systems of logic. A lot of the concepts are very interesting and abstract, but Sun-joo does an amazing job explaining what's going on and makes it very accessible (almost trivial) to anyone who's vaguely has a math/logic background, even though the concepts themselves are not easy. If you're interested in the philosophy of logic or perhaps just want to know about the limits of mathematics and formal systems, this is the class for you! I highly recommend this class to any CS person who's interested in Turing's/Church's thesis and math people who want to think about the underlying structure in all of mathematics. 

Please please take this course with Sun-joo!
Yes, particularly if you are a math major looking for a humanities credit, this course is great.
Prof. Shin is amazing, try to go to office hours if you can

Yes, for anyone who's is interested in understanding the underlying logic and philosophical ideas behind computability and the historical effort mathematicians put into axiomatizing mathematics. Professor Shin is a funny and engaging lecture, and she is really nice. The course material is really interesting and the workload is relatively low.
Yes! Especially if they are interested in the intersection of math and philosophy.
Definitely, Professor Shin is a great teacher.
Yes! It's an engaging course that teaches you to think a little differently than most other philosophy/math classes, and Sunjoo is a delight.
Absolutely, I developed a much deeper insight into the truth of math and logic which I thoroughly appreciate.
If you are interested in the topics yes and have strong math and/or comp sci background yes
Yes, good teacher.

Easily! If you find the content interesting, this is a lovely course to take. The workload is quite light, but enough to get a pretty deep understanding of the course content. Godel's theorems are one both very important to math and largely misunderstood  take this opportunity to learn them properly!
Any student thinking about about a focus in logic or philosophy should consider taking this class.
